content.question: A region of space has a hollow hemisphere of radius <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>. A uniform magnetic field <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> passes through the hemisphere at an angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> as shown. Which of the following correctly describes the magnetic flux through the curved surface of the hemisphere?

choices.label: The net flux through the curved surface is zero.

The flux through the curved surface can only be found by integrating <math alttext="the contour integral of vector B dot d vector A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>∮</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>·</mo><mi>d</mi><mover accent="true"><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></mstyle></math> over the curved area.
The amount of flux out of the curved surface is equal to the amount of flux into the left circular face of the hemisphere.
The flux through the surface is the same no matter the orientation of the hemisphere.

content.answer: The amount of flux out of the curved surface is equal to the amount of flux into the left circular face of the hemisphere.
